objective: To introduce the concept of money and its purpose.
explanation:
• Money is a tool we use to exchange goods and services.
• It has different forms, such as coins and bills.
• Each coin and bill has a specific value.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Money Sorting
Materials Needed: Mix of real or play Indian coins and bills, sorting trays or bowls.
Steps to Follow:
• Provide a mix of ₹1, ₹2, ₹5, ₹10 coins and ₹10, ₹20, ₹50 bills.
• Ask the child to separate coins and bills into two groups.
• Further sort them by value.
• Encourage the child to count each group aloud.
What Should Be Achieved:
Child identifies money by form and value.
What is Gained:
• Visual classification
• Basic counting
• Early money-handling skill
materials: Mix of real or play Indian coins and bills
steps: Provide a mix of ₹1, ₹2, ₹5, ₹10 coins and ₹10, ₹20, ₹50 bills.
Ask the child to separate coins and bills into two groups.
Further sort them by value.
Encourage the child to count each group aloud.
activities.achieved: Child identifies money by form and value.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Shopping Pretend Play
Materials Needed: Play money, toys or snacks, table or shelf for setup.
Steps to Follow:
• Set up a pretend store.
• Give the child play money.
• Let them “buy” items.
• Practice giving money and receiving change.
What Should Be Achieved:
Basic money exchange understanding.
What is Gained:
• Real-life simulation
• Confidence using money
steps: Set up a pretend store.
Give the child play money.
Let them “buy” items.
Practice giving money and receiving change.

objective: To learn about different coins and bills and their values.
explanation:
• Introduce common coins and bills used in your country.
• Explain the value of each coin and bill.
• Demonstrate how to count money using different combinations.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Coin Recognition Game
Materials Needed: Real or play coins and bills, coin/bill chart.
Steps to Follow:
• Show the child a coin or bill.
• Ask them to name its value.
• Match it to the correct space on the chart.
What Should Be Achieved:
Recognize and name common money types.
What is Gained:
• Memory skills
• Visual identification
• Currency knowledge
materials: Real or play coins and bills
steps: Show the child a coin or bill.
Ask them to name its value.
Match it to the correct space on the chart.
activities.achieved: Recognize and name common money types.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Money Matching
Materials Needed: Pairs of coins/bills or matching cards.
Steps to Follow:
• Lay out the cards face down.
• Take turns flipping cards to find matches.
• Match same values together.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand money equivalence.
What is Gained:
• Matching skills
• Value recognition
materials: Pairs of coins/bills or matching cards.
steps: Lay out the cards face down.
Take turns flipping cards to find matches.
Match same values together.

objective: To understand the difference between spending and saving money.
explanation:
• Spending means using money to buy things.
• Saving means keeping money for later.
• Both are important for smart decisions.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Piggy Bank Challenge
Materials Needed: Piggy bank, coins, paper chart.
Steps to Follow:
• Give child coins daily/weekly.
• Ask them to drop part of it into the piggy bank.
• Track savings on a chart.
What Should Be Achieved:
Child practices saving regularly.
What is Gained:
• Patience
• Planning
• Discipline
steps: Give child coins daily/weekly.
Ask them to drop part of it into the piggy bank.
Track savings on a chart.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Spending vs. Saving Game
Materials Needed: Toy catalog, play money.
Steps to Follow:
• Show child a toy they want.
• Offer small amount of play money.
• Discuss if they want to spend now or save for a bigger toy.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand choice-making with money.
What is Gained:
• Decision-making
• Goal setting
steps: Show child a toy they want.
Offer small amount of play money.
Discuss if they want to spend now or save for a bigger toy.

objective: To introduce the concept of budgeting and planning spending.
explanation:
• A budget is a plan for money use.
• It helps us make smart choices.
• We list income and expenses.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Create a Simple Budget
Materials Needed: Paper, markers, play money.
Steps to Follow:
• List categories (food, toys, savings).
• Allocate amounts to each.
• Draw and decorate a simple chart.
What Should Be Achieved:
Visualize budgeting.
What is Gained:
• Awareness of needs vs wants
• Planning ability
steps: List categories (food, toys, savings).
Allocate amounts to each.
Draw and decorate a simple chart.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Budgeting Game
Materials Needed: Pretend store setup, price tags.
Steps to Follow:
• Give the child limited play money.
• Let them "shop" within budget.
• Ask questions about their choices.
What Should Be Achieved:
Prioritize spending.
What is Gained:
• Critical thinking
• Math application
steps: Give the child limited play money.
Let them "shop" within budget.
Ask questions about their choices.

objective: To learn how to shop on a budget and make smart choices.
explanation:
• Compare prices and choose wisely.
• Make a list to avoid extra purchases.
• Stick to the budget when shopping.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Grocery Store Field Trip
Materials Needed: Grocery store visit, list, pen.
Steps to Follow:
• Create a basic list with the child.
• Visit a local store.
• Let the child help choose items within budget.
What Should Be Achieved:
Real-life money planning.
What is Gained:
• Price comparison
• Responsibility
steps: Create a basic list with the child.
Visit a local store.
Let the child help choose items within budget.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Shopping List Game
Materials Needed: Toy food items, play money, written list.
Steps to Follow:
• Child uses list to “shop.”
• Stick to items only on the list.
What Should Be Achieved:
List-following and self-control.
What is Gained:
• Impulse control
• Organization
steps: Child uses list to “shop.”
Stick to items only on the list.

objective: To practice counting money accurately.
explanation:
• Add coin and bill values.
• Count slowly and carefully.
• Combine coins to make larger values.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Money Counting Game
Materials Needed: Play coins/bills, calculator (optional).
Steps to Follow:
• Child receives mixed denominations.
• Count each pile’s total.
• Double-check using a calculator.
What Should Be Achieved:
Accurate money counting.
What is Gained:
• Math practice
• Confidence in handling money
steps: Child receives mixed denominations.
Count each pile’s total.
Double
check using a calculator.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Real-Life Transactions
Materials Needed: Coins, snacks, price tags.
Steps to Follow:
• Assign a price to real snacks.
• Have child “buy” them using exact change.
What Should Be Achieved:
Apply counting in real-world.
What is Gained:
• Practical skills
• Addition/subtraction
steps: Assign a price to real snacks.
Have child “buy” them using exact change.

objective: To set and achieve financial goals.
explanation:
• Goals give purpose to saving.
• We track progress to stay motivated.
• Goals can be big or small.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Goal Setting Worksheet
Materials Needed: Printable worksheet, crayons.
Steps to Follow:
• Ask child to draw or write a goal.
• Add steps to reach the goal.
• Decorate for motivation.
What Should Be Achieved:
Visual goal planning.
What is Gained:
• Creativity
• Planning
steps: Ask child to draw or write a goal.
Add steps to reach the goal.
Decorate for motivation.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Savings Challenge
Materials Needed: Jar or piggy bank, calendar.
Steps to Follow:
• Choose an amount to save each day/week.
• Mark progress on calendar.
• Celebrate when goal is met.
What Should Be Achieved:
Persistence in saving.
What is Gained:
• Dedication
• Reward motivation
steps: Choose an amount to save each day/week.
Mark progress on calendar.
Celebrate when goal is met.

objective: To understand the difference between good and bad debt.
explanation:
• Good debt helps reach goals.
• Bad debt causes problems.
• Be responsible with borrowing.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Debt Scenario Game
Materials Needed: Flashcards with scenarios.
Steps to Follow:
• Read a situation (e.g., borrowing for school).
• Ask child if it’s good or bad debt.
• Discuss why.
What Should Be Achieved:
Debt decision-making.
What is Gained:
• Logical thinking
• Financial awareness
steps: Read a situation (e.g., borrowing for school).
Ask child if it’s good or bad debt.
Discuss why.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Debt Consequences Discussion
Materials Needed: Storybook or discussion prompts.
Steps to Follow:
• Talk about what happens if someone doesn’t repay debt.
• Use age-appropriate stories.
What Should Be Achieved:
Awareness of responsibility.
What is Gained:
• Cause-effect understanding
• Ethics
steps: Talk about what happens if someone doesn’t repay debt.
Use age
appropriate stories.

objective: To teach the importance of financial responsibility.
explanation:
• Make smart choices with money.
• Avoid impulse buys.
• Save for the future.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Financial Decision-Making Game
Materials Needed: Cards with financial decisions.
Steps to Follow:
• Present a situation (buy candy or save?).
• Child chooses and explains why.
• Discuss better options.
What Should Be Achieved:
Thoughtful decision-making.
What is Gained:
• Responsibility
• Values
steps: Present a situation (buy candy or save?).
Child chooses and explains why.
Discuss better options.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Financial Responsibility Pledge
Materials Needed: Printable pledge sheet, crayons.
Steps to Follow:
• Child writes or draws how they’ll be responsible.
• Sign and display.
What Should Be Achieved:
Commit to habits.
What is Gained:
• Accountability
• Sense of pride
steps: Child writes or draws how they’ll be responsible.
Sign and display.

objective: To introduce the concept of long-term financial planning.
explanation:
• Planning helps reach big goals.
• Start early to build habits.
• Think about future needs.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Future Planning Exercise
Materials Needed: Drawing paper, markers.
Steps to Follow:
• Ask what the child wants to be when grown up.
• Draw or write the dream.
• Discuss what money they’ll need.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect goals with finance.
What is Gained:
• Long-term thinking
• Financial dreaming
steps: Ask what the child wants to be when grown up.
Draw or write the dream.
Discuss what money they’ll need.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Financial Role-Playing
Materials Needed: Costumes, props, play money.
Steps to Follow:
• Child acts as an adult buying groceries, paying bills.
• Use pretend money.
What Should Be Achieved:
Real-world financial awareness.
What is Gained:
• Imagination
• Adult perspective
steps: Child acts as an adult buying groceries, paying bills.
Use pretend money.

objective: Introduce the concept of earning money through work or chores.
explanation:
• People earn money by doing work or chores.
• Earning money helps us buy things or save for future needs.
• Work can be fun and rewarding.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Pretend Job Play
Materials Needed: Toy tools, toy kitchen items, paper, crayons, play money.
Steps to Follow:
• Set up different “jobs” like cooking, cleaning, or fixing things.
• Assign tasks and offer pretend payment for completion.
• Let the child collect money after each job.
What Should Be Achieved: Understanding that work can earn money.
What is Gained:
• Early work ethic
• Responsibility
• Real-life simulation
steps: Set up different “jobs” like cooking, cleaning, or fixing things.
Assign tasks and offer pretend payment for completion.
Let the child collect money after each job.
activities.achieved: Understanding that work can earn money.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Chore Reward Chart
Materials Needed: Chart paper, stickers, markers, chore pictures.
Steps to Follow:
• Create a weekly chart listing age-appropriate chores.
• Set a pretend amount of money earned for each chore.
• Add a sticker every time a chore is completed.
• Exchange stickers for pretend money at the end of the week.
What Should Be Achieved: Linking work to earning.
What is Gained:
• Motivation to complete tasks
• Value of consistency
steps: Create a weekly chart listing age
appropriate chores.
Set a pretend amount of money earned for each chore.
Add a sticker every time a chore is completed.
Exchange stickers for pretend money at the end of the week.

objective: Differentiate between needs (essential items) and wants (desirable items).
explanation:
• Needs are things we must have to live (like food, clothes, and shelter).
• Wants are things we would like but don’t need to survive.
• It's important to spend money on needs before wants.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Needs vs. Wants Sorting
Materials Needed: Picture cards of various items (toys, clothes, food, games, house).
Steps to Follow:
• Show each picture and ask if it's a need or a want.
• Sort pictures into “Need” and “Want” bowls.
• Talk through the reason behind each placement.
What Should Be Achieved: Understanding the difference between needs and wants.
What is Gained:
• Critical thinking
• Smart spending skills
steps: Show each picture and ask if it's a need or a want.
Sort pictures into “Need” and “Want” bowls.
Talk through the reason behind each placement.
activities.achieved: Understanding the difference between needs and wants.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Budget Shopping Role Play
Materials Needed: Play money, toy items, paper for budget.
Steps to Follow:
• Give the child a limited budget.
• Present a mix of needs and wants in a pretend store.
• Let the child decide what to buy first.
• Discuss choices afterward.
What Should Be Achieved: Prioritizing needs over wants.
What is Gained:
• Decision-making
• Simple budgeting sense
steps: Give the child a limited budget.
Present a mix of needs and wants in a pretend store.
Let the child decide what to buy first.
Discuss choices afterward.

objective: Explore different saving strategies.
explanation:
• Saving helps us reach future goals.
• We can use different tools like piggy banks or savings jars.
• Having a plan makes saving easier.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Piggy Bank Goal Setting
Materials Needed: Piggy bank or jar, paper, crayons.
Steps to Follow:
• Ask the child to draw something they want to save for (e.g., a toy).
• Label the jar with the goal.
• Add coins every time money is “earned.”
What Should Be Achieved: Purposeful saving.
What is Gained:
• Goal-setting
• Patience and planning
steps: Ask the child to draw something they want to save for (e.g., a toy).
Label the jar with the goal.
Add coins every time money is “earned.”

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Saving Jar Categories
Materials Needed: 3 jars (Save, Spend, Share), coins or play money, labels.
Steps to Follow:
• Introduce the concept of dividing money into categories.
• Have the child sort money into the jars with explanations.
• Revisit weekly to check progress.
What Should Be Achieved: Learning to save with purpose.
What is Gained:
• Value-based saving
• Money organization
steps: Introduce the concept of dividing money into categories.
Have the child sort money into the jars with explanations.
Revisit weekly to check progress.

• Add coins every time money is “earned.”
What Should Be Achieved: Purposeful saving.
What is Gained:
• Goal-setting
• Patience and planning
originalData.activity2:
Saving Jar Categories
Materials Needed: 3 jars (Save, Spend, Share), coins or play money, labels.
Steps to Follow:
• Introduce the concept of dividing money into categories.
• Have the child sort money into the jars with explanations.
• Revisit weekly to check progress.
What Should Be Achieved: Learning to save with purpose.
What is Gained:
• Value-based saving
• Money organization

objective: Practice counting money and making change.
explanation:
• Making change means giving back the right amount of money after a purchase.
• It helps us understand how much things cost.
• It's a fun way to practice math.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Play Shop Transactions
Materials Needed: Play money, price tags, toy items.
Steps to Follow:
• Set up a shop with price-labeled items.
• Child “buys” items with play money.
• Practice calculating and giving back change.
What Should Be Achieved: Understanding transactions and change.
What is Gained:
• Money math
• Confidence handling money

labeled items.

Practice calculating and giving back change.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Make the Right Change

• Set prices and give the child an amount that requires change.
• Let the child calculate the right coins to return.
• Check and discuss.
What Should Be Achieved: Accurate money handling.
What is Gained:
• Calculation
• Logical reasoning

objective: Learn about different currencies around the world.
explanation:
• Different countries use different types of money called currency.
• Each currency has its own name, symbol, and value.
• It’s fun to learn about money from other places.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
World Money Exploration
Materials Needed: Images of currencies (dollars, euros, yen, etc.), globe or world map.
Steps to Follow:
• Match currency images to countries on the map.
• Talk about symbols and values.
• Compare how they look different from Indian currency.
What Should Be Achieved: Awareness of global money.
What is Gained:
• Cultural learning
• Currency recognition
steps: Match currency images to countries on the map.
Talk about symbols and values.
Compare how they look different from Indian currency.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Currency Exchange Pretend Play
Materials Needed: Play currencies, labels with exchange rates, pretend travel tickets.
Steps to Follow:
• Set up a travel booth with pretend exchange rates.
• Have the child “travel” and exchange Indian currency.
• Use new currency to “buy” items from that country.
What Should Be Achieved: Understanding of currency exchange.
What is Gained:
• Math in context
• World exposure
steps: Set up a travel booth with pretend exchange rates.
Have the child “travel” and exchange Indian currency.
Use new currency to “buy” items from that country.

objective: Recognize persuasive language and sales tactics in advertisements.
explanation:
• Ads try to make us want to buy things.
• They use bright colors, catchy words, and fun characters.
• It's important to think before buying something we see in an ad.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Ad Detective
Materials Needed: Magazine ads, scissors, glue, worksheet.
Steps to Follow:
• Cut out ads and identify catchy words or visuals.
• Discuss what the ad is trying to make you do.
• Sort into “Honest” or “Persuasive.”
What Should Be Achieved: Recognizing sales techniques.
What is Gained:
• Media awareness
• Thinking skills
steps: Cut out ads and identify catchy words or visuals.
Discuss what the ad is trying to make you do.
Sort into “Honest” or “Persuasive.”

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Make Your Own Honest Ad
Materials Needed: Paper, crayons, a toy or object.
Steps to Follow:
• Ask the child to pick an item to “sell.”
• Help them create an ad that shows the real features, not exaggerations.
• Present to family or friends.
What Should Be Achieved: Honest communication.
What is Gained:
• Expression
• Awareness of truth in ads

objective: Create a basic budget for specific needs or wants.
explanation:
• A budget helps us plan how to use our money.
• We can divide our money into different parts—spending, saving, and giving.
• Budgeting helps us make smart choices.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Trip Budget Planning
Materials Needed: Paper, play money, picture cutouts (food, ticket, souvenirs).
Steps to Follow:
• Choose a pretend destination.
• Assign prices to travel, food, and fun items.
• Let the child divide money based on priority.
What Should Be Achieved: Budget basics.
What is Gained:
• Allocation skills
• Financial planning
steps: Choose a pretend destination.
Assign prices to travel, food, and fun items.
Let the child divide money based on priority.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
My Pocket Money Plan
Materials Needed: Chart with 3 columns: Save, Spend, Share; stickers; play money.
Steps to Follow:
• Ask what the child would do with ₹100.
• Help split the amount among the columns.
• Talk through each choice.
What Should Be Achieved: Personalized budgeting.
What is Gained:
• Decision-making
• Money sense
steps: Ask what the child would do with ₹100.

Talk through each choice.

objective: Introduce the concept of credit cards and responsible usage.
explanation:
• A credit card lets you borrow money to pay later.
• We must always pay back what we borrow, or we’ll owe more.
• It’s important to use credit responsibly.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Credit Card Simulation
Materials Needed: Fake credit card, pretend store items, play money.
Steps to Follow:
• Role-play shopping with a pretend card.
• Keep a written note of what is “owed.”
• Repay using play money.
What Should Be Achieved: Borrowing and repayment.
What is Gained:
• Understanding credit
• Basic accountability
steps: Role
play shopping with a pretend card.
Keep a written note of what is “owed.”
Repay using play money.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Good vs. Bad Credit Choices
Materials Needed: Flashcards with scenarios (e.g., buying food vs. toys with credit).
Steps to Follow:
• Read each card aloud.
• Ask the child to decide if it’s a smart use of credit.
• Discuss why or why not.
What Should Be Achieved: Responsible decisions.
What is Gained:
• Critical thinking
• Practical reasoning
materials: buying food vs. toys with credit).
steps: Read each card aloud.
Ask the child to decide if it’s a smart use of credit.
Discuss why or why not.

objective: Develop critical thinking when comparing prices and offers.
explanation:
• Sometimes the same item costs different amounts in different places.
• Comparing prices helps us get the best deal.
• Coupons and discounts help save money.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Price Tag Hunt
Materials Needed: Same item with different prices (real or pretend), paper to record.
Steps to Follow:
• Show the same toy at different prices.
• Let the child compare and choose the best value.
• Talk about “why” choices were made.
What Should Be Achieved: Price comparison.
What is Gained:
• Evaluation
• Shopping smarts
materials: Same item with different prices (real or pretend)

Talk about “why” choices were made.

Coupon Sorting Game

Steps to Follow:
• Sort coupons by usefulness for needs vs. wants.
• Match the best coupon to different items.
What Should Be Achieved: Using discounts smartly.
What is Gained:
• Deal evaluation
• Math practice

objective: Introduce the basic idea of taxes and their purpose.
explanation:
• Taxes are money we pay to help the community.
• Taxes pay for things like roads, schools, and parks.
• Everyone pays a little to help everyone.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Sales Tax Pretend Play
Materials Needed: Play money, toy items, simple tax chart (e.g., add ₹1 per item).
Steps to Follow:
• Child buys items with marked prices.
• Add a fixed tax per item.
• Collect and count total money.
What Should Be Achieved: Awareness of tax.
What is Gained:
• Simple math
• Community understanding
steps: Child buys items with marked prices.
Add a fixed tax per item.
Collect and count total money.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Where Taxes Go Discussion
Materials Needed: Flashcards of roads, schools, parks, hospitals.
Steps to Follow:
• Match public services to the concept of tax funding.
• Role-play being a community helper funded by taxes.
What Should Be Achieved: Community link to taxes.
What is Gained:
• Civic sense
• Shared responsibility

play being a community helper funded by taxes.

objective: Introduce the concept of investing and its potential benefits.
explanation:
• Investing means putting money into something that can grow over time. 
• People invest in things like stocks or businesses. 
• Investing can have risks and rewards.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Stock Market Simulation:
• Materials Needed: Pretend stock cards, fake money, chart paper.
• Steps to Follow: Simulate a week of stock trading where kids choose stocks and track changes.
• What Should Be Achieved: Kids understand the concept of buying low and selling high.
• What is Gained: Introduction to investment and market behavior.
steps: Simulate a week of stock trading where kids choose stocks and track changes.
activities.achieved: Kids understand the concept of buying low and selling high.
gained: Introduction to investment and market behavior.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Savings vs. Investing:
• Materials Needed: Two piggy banks, coins, chart paper.
• Steps to Follow: Save money in one bank, “invest” money in another with pretend returns. Track results over time.
• What Should Be Achieved: Recognize growth potential through investing.
• What is Gained: Understanding difference between saving and investing.
steps: Save money in one bank, “invest” money in another with pretend returns. Track results over time.
gained: Understanding difference between saving and investing.

objective: Create a comprehensive budget and financial plan.

• Financial planning means thinking about both now and the future. 
• We can set goals and track our spending.

• Steps to Follow: Fill in worksheet with income, expenses, and savings. Use real-life items like food and toys for categories.
• What Should Be Achieved: Kids understand how to plan spending.
• What is Gained: Early budgeting and prioritizing needs vs wants.

• What is Gained: Strategic thinking and goal setting.

objective: Explain the concept of compound interest and its power for growth.
explanation:
• Compound interest means you earn interest on both your savings and the interest it earns. 
• The more time you save, the more money you can grow. 
• It's a great way to build wealth over time.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Compound Interest Calculator:
• Materials Needed: Simple online calculator, savings chart.
• Steps to Follow: Input savings amounts and see how they grow with interest.
• What Should Be Achieved: Understand how money grows faster with compound interest.
• What is Gained: Appreciation of long-term saving.
steps: Input savings amounts and see how they grow with interest.
activities.achieved: Understand how money grows faster with compound interest.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Savings Challenge:
• Materials Needed: Jars, stickers, coins.
• Steps to Follow: Add pretend interest weekly to savings jars. Track totals.
• What Should Be Achieved: See effects of reinvesting.
• What is Gained: Visual and tangible grasp of compound interest.

gained: Visual and tangible grasp of compound interest.

objective: Understand the importance of credit and responsible debt management.

objective: Introduce reliable sources for financial information and education.

topic: The Economy and How It Works
objective: Introduce the basics of how the economy functions.
explanation:
• The economy is how people make, buy, and sell things.
• Everyone has a role: workers, businesses, and consumers.
• We use money to buy goods (things) and services (help from others).

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Community Role Game
Materials Needed: Costumes, props, pretend money
Steps to Follow:
1. Assign each child a community role (baker, teacher, etc.)
2. Set up stations and let them exchange goods/services
3. Use pretend money to simulate transactions
What Should Be Achieved: Children understand the roles in an economy
What is Gained: Experience with how people contribute to a working economy.
steps:
1. Assign each child a community role (baker, teacher, etc.)
2. Set up stations and let them exchange goods/services
3. Use pretend money to simulate transactions
activities.achieved: Children understand the roles in an economy
gained: Experience with how people contribute to a working economy.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Goods and Services Sorting
Materials Needed: Flashcards or cut-outs with images
Steps to Follow:
1. Show children different flashcards
2. Ask them to sort each as either a "good" or "service"
What Should Be Achieved: Identify examples of goods and services
What is Gained: Understanding the difference between tangible items and helpful actions.
steps:
1. Show children different flashcards
2. Ask them to sort each as either a "good" or "service"

objective: Teach decision-making when choosing how to spend money.
explanation:
• Money is limited, so we must make smart choices.
• Comparing prices, quality, and needs vs. wants helps us spend wisely.
• Waiting before buying can help avoid impulse buying.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Price Comparison Activity
Materials Needed: Printouts or real items with prices
Steps to Follow:
1. Show multiple versions of similar items
2. Compare prices and quality
3. Ask children to pick the best choice and explain why
What Should Be Achieved: Ability to choose value over price
What is Gained: Smart consumer decision-making skills.
materials: Printouts or real items with prices
steps:
1. Show multiple versions of similar items
2. Compare prices and quality
3. Ask children to pick the best choice and explain why
activities.achieved: Ability to choose value over price

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Spending Reflection
Materials Needed: Worksheet or blank paper
Steps to Follow:
1. Ask child to think of a recent purchase
2. Have them write/draw whether it was worth it
3. Discuss alternatives
What Should Be Achieved: Reflection on spending choices
What is Gained: Critical thinking about past financial behavior.
steps:
1. Ask child to think of a recent purchase
2. Have them write/draw whether it was worth it
3. Discuss alternatives
gained: Critical thinking about past financial behavior.

topic: The Value of Time and Money
objective: Help children understand that time is also a valuable resource.
explanation:
• We often trade time for money (working).
• Time management helps us do more with less stress.
• Balancing work, rest, and fun is important.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Time Budgeting Activity
Materials Needed: Printable schedule grid, markers
Steps to Follow:
1. Fill out a day’s schedule
2. Allocate time to tasks like homework, play, chores
3. Discuss balance
What Should Be Achieved: Awareness of how we spend time
What is Gained: Introduction to time management and trade-offs.
steps:
1. Fill out a day’s schedule
2. Allocate time to tasks like homework, play, chores
3. Discuss balance
activities.achieved: Awareness of how we spend time
gained: Introduction to time management and trade

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Work for Time Challenge
Materials Needed: Timer, chore list, reward chart
Steps to Follow:
1. Set up small timed chores
2. Reward completed tasks with tokens
3. Trade tokens for a fun activity
What Should Be Achieved: Link between time and effort
What is Gained: Value of time spent earning rewards.
steps:
1. Set up small timed chores
2. Reward completed tasks with tokens
3. Trade tokens for a fun activity
gained: Value of time spent earning rewards.

originalData.objective: Understand the role of banks and how they help manage money.
originalData.explanation:
• · Banks keep our money safe and help us save.
• · They offer services like savings accounts and loans.
• · We can deposit and withdraw money through banks.
originalData.activity1:
Bank Visit Simulation
Materials Needed: Play money, containers labeled as “Savings Account,” “Checking Account,” teller table
Steps to Follow: 1. Set up a pretend bank. 2. Guide child through deposit/withdrawal. 3. Use play money to simulate bank use.
What Should Be Achieved: Understanding banking basics.
What is Gained: Real-world application of deposit/withdrawal.
originalData.activity2:
Bank Service Match
Materials Needed: Flashcards showing bank services and definitions (e.g., loans, savings, checking)
Steps to Follow: 1. Match cards of services to definitions. 2. Review each correctly matched set.
What Should Be Achieved: Service identification.
What is Gained: Familiarity with types of banking services.

objective: Learn how interest works when saving money in a bank.
explanation:
• · Interest is extra money banks give us for saving.
• · The more we save and longer we keep it, the more we earn.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Interest Growth Chart
Materials Needed: Chart paper, markers, play money
Steps to Follow: 1. Draw a savings timeline. 2. Add interest to savings each week. 3. Show how savings grow.
What Should Be Achieved: See savings grow.
What is Gained: Introduction to compounding.
steps: 1. Draw a savings timeline. 2. Add interest to savings each week. 3. Show how savings grow.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Interest Guessing Game
Materials Needed: Example savings amounts, simple interest rate
Steps to Follow: 1. Ask child to guess interest earned on amounts. 2. Reveal actual results.
What Should Be Achieved: Predict growth.
What is Gained: Basic understanding of earning interest.
steps: 1. Ask child to guess interest earned on amounts. 2. Reveal actual results.

objective: Understand different types of investments and risk levels.
explanation:
• · We can invest in stocks, bonds, or real estate.
• · Investments grow over time but carry risk.
• · Some are safer but slower-growing.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Investment Sorting Game
Materials Needed: Cards labeled with investments (e.g., stocks, savings, bonds)
Steps to Follow: 1. Sort cards into low, medium, high risk. 2. Discuss each.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand risk categories.
What is Gained: Decision-making skills in investing.
steps: 1. Sort cards into low, medium, high risk. 2. Discuss each.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Build a Mini Portfolio
Materials Needed: Paper, stickers for investments
Steps to Follow: 1. Child chooses a mix of investments. 2. Assign pretend returns. 3. Add up final results.
What Should Be Achieved: Portfolio creation.
What is Gained: Awareness of diversification.
steps: 1. Child chooses a mix of investments. 2. Assign pretend returns. 3. Add up final results.

objective: Identify different ways people earn income.
explanation:
• · Income is money we earn from work, businesses, or investments.
• · Types: earned, passive, portfolio.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Job Match Game
Materials Needed: Job cards (e.g., teacher, artist, landlord), income type labels
Steps to Follow: 1. Match job to income type. 2. Review answers.
What Should Be Achieved: Link work to earnings.
What is Gained: Different income types understanding.
steps: 1. Match job to income type. 2. Review answers.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Income Sources Drawing
Materials Needed: Paper, crayons
Steps to Follow: 1. Child draws 3 ways to earn money. 2. Label them. 3. Discuss each.
What Should Be Achieved: Illustrate income ideas.
What is Gained: Creativity + concept recall.
steps: 1. Child draws 3 ways to earn money. 2. Label them. 3. Discuss each.

objective: Learn about making choices and what we give up.
explanation:
• · Choosing one thing means giving up another.
• · This is called opportunity cost.
• · Helps us make better decisions.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Spending Choice Game
Materials Needed: Cards with items (e.g., toy vs. book)
Steps to Follow: 1. Present two items, limited money. 2. Pick one, discuss what’s given up.
What Should Be Achieved: Realize trade-offs.
What is Gained: Decision-making awareness.
steps: 1. Present two items, limited money. 2. Pick one, discuss what’s given up.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Story Scenarios
Materials Needed: Short story cards with spending choices
Steps to Follow: 1. Read story. 2. Ask “What was the opportunity cost?” 3. Reflect on choices.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand cost of decisions.
What is Gained: Real-world thinking on spending.
materials: Short story cards with spending choices
steps: 1. Read story. 2. Ask “What was the opportunity cost?” 3. Reflect on choices.

objective: Learn to budget for specific occasions.
explanation:
• · Events like birthdays need budgeting.
• · Plan how much to spend on each part.
• · Avoid overspending.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Party Budget Plan
Materials Needed: Budget worksheet, play money
Steps to Follow: 1. Set event budget. 2. Allocate to categories (food, gifts). 3. Stay within limits.
What Should Be Achieved: Plan spending.
What is Gained: Event-specific budgeting skills.
steps: 1. Set event budget. 2. Allocate to categories (food, gifts). 3. Stay within limits.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Budget Tracker Activity
Materials Needed: Tracker sheet, stickers or coins
Steps to Follow: 1. Track pretend purchases. 2. Monitor remaining budget.
What Should Be Achieved: Watch spending.
What is Gained: Tracking and responsibility.
steps: 1. Track pretend purchases. 2. Monitor remaining budget.

objective: Understand how digital payments work.
explanation:
• · We can shop and pay using apps.
• · Digital money works through cards or accounts.
• · Be careful online.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Online Store Simulation
Materials Needed: Pretend items, play debit cards, shopping table
Steps to Follow: 1. Set up shop. 2. Child “buys” items. 3. Use play cards to pay.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand online payments.
What is Gained: Digital payment practice.
steps: 1. Set up shop. 2. Child “buys” items. 3. Use play cards to pay.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Safe Online Payment Tips
Materials Needed: Flashcards with good/bad online habits
Steps to Follow: 1. Show behavior card. 2. Decide safe/unsafe. 3. Discuss why.
What Should Be Achieved: Digital safety awareness.
What is Gained: Cyber-smart money habits.
steps: 1. Show behavior card. 2. Decide safe/unsafe. 3. Discuss why.

objective: Learn why people use insurance and how it works.
explanation:
• · Insurance protects against unexpected costs.
• · Pay a little now to avoid big bills later.
• · Many types exist.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Risk Role-Play
Materials Needed: Props for bad events (e.g., broken toy)
Steps to Follow: 1. Act out a mishap. 2. Ask how insurance helps. 3. Explain coverage.
What Should Be Achieved: See purpose of insurance.
What is Gained: Preparedness and protection thinking.
steps: 1. Act out a mishap. 2. Ask how insurance helps. 3. Explain coverage.

activities.originalText:
Insurance Match Game
Materials Needed: Cards with insurance types and examples
Steps to Follow: 1. Match insurance to item/event. 2. Discuss matches.
What Should Be Achieved: Identify insurance roles.
What is Gained: Understanding what insurance covers.

objective: Introduction to how credit scores and borrowing work.
explanation:
• · A credit score shows how trustworthy someone is with money.
• · Paying on time builds good credit.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Credit Score Tracker
Materials Needed: Score sheet, scenario cards
Steps to Follow: 1. Read scenarios. 2. Add/subtract points based on behavior. 3. Reflect on score change.
What Should Be Achieved: Learn score consequences.
What is Gained: Credit behavior awareness.
steps: 1. Read scenarios. 2. Add/subtract points based on behavior. 3. Reflect on score change.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Borrowing Game
Materials Needed: Play money, loan cards
Steps to Follow: 1. Child borrows money for a pretend item. 2. Set payback terms. 3. Track repayments.
What Should Be Achieved: Learn about borrowing responsibility.
What is Gained: Understanding debt and repayment.
steps: 1. Child borrows money for a pretend item. 2. Set payback terms. 3. Track repayments.

objective: Understand how countries trade and affect each other’s economies.
explanation:
• · Countries trade goods/services.
• · Currencies differ.
• · Economies are connected.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Country Trading Game
Materials Needed: Country and item cards, pretend currencies
Steps to Follow: 1. Assign countries. 2. Trade items using play money. 3. Convert currencies if needed.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand global trade.
What is Gained: Big-picture economic thinking.
steps: 1. Assign countries. 2. Trade items using play money. 3. Convert currencies if needed.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Import/Export Match
Materials Needed: Cards with countries and their exports
Steps to Follow: 1. Match items to countries. 2. Discuss why they’re known for it.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand international trade.
What is Gained: Geography + finance link.

objective: To understand online banking, mobile apps, and digital transactions.
explanation:
• · Digital banking allows us to manage money using phones or computers.
• · We can check balances, transfer money, and pay bills online.
• · It's important to keep our login info safe.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Banking App Demo
Materials Needed: Mock banking app interface (paper or digital), phone/tablet
Steps to Follow: 1. Show app functions like checking balance or transferring money. 2. Let child explore buttons and discuss features.
What Should Be Achieved: Recognize banking app features.
What is Gained: Digital money confidence.
materials: Mock banking app interface (paper or digital)
steps: 1. Show app functions like checking balance or transferring money. 2. Let child explore buttons and discuss features.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Login Safety Activity
Materials Needed: Password cards (strong/weak), list of safe online practices
Steps to Follow: 1. Compare weak vs. strong passwords. 2. Match safe habits (e.g., don’t share passwords).
What Should Be Achieved: Know how to stay safe online.
What is Gained: Awareness of digital security.
steps: 1. Compare weak vs. strong passwords. 2. Match safe habits (e.g., don’t share passwords).
activities.achieved: Know how to stay safe online.

objective: To understand how choices impact finances and resources.
explanation:
• · Every choice has a cost, called an opportunity cost.
• · We make economic choices daily, like how to spend time or money.
• · Learning to choose wisely helps us use resources better.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Choice Comparison Chart
Materials Needed: Chart with 2 columns (Choice A vs. Choice B), pencils
Steps to Follow: 1. Pick a spending scenario (e.g., toy vs. book). 2. Write out what is gained/lost with each.
What Should Be Achieved: Visualize opportunity cost.
What is Gained: Smart thinking in decisions.
materials: Chart with 2 columns (Choice A vs. Choice B)
steps: 1. Pick a spending scenario (e.g., toy vs. book). 2. Write out what is gained/lost with each.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Daily Choices Journal
Materials Needed: Notebook, pen
Steps to Follow: 1. Track choices for 1 day (e.g., spent $1 on candy). 2. Reflect what else could’ve been done with that money/time.
What Should Be Achieved: Awareness of decisions.
What is Gained: Practical connection to opportunity cost.
steps: 1. Track choices for 1 day (e.g., spent $1 on candy). 2. Reflect what else could’ve been done with that money/time.

objective: To introduce the concept of insurance and how it protects us.
explanation:
• · Insurance helps us pay for big problems, like accidents or damage.
• · We pay a small amount regularly (a premium) for protection.
• · It’s a way to share risk and feel secure.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Risk Simulation
Materials Needed: Toy items, “accident” cards (e.g., toy broke, lost)
Steps to Follow: 1. Draw a card showing something going wrong. 2. Discuss what happens with vs. without insurance.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand protection role.
What is Gained: Preparedness awareness.
steps: 1. Draw a card showing something going wrong. 2. Discuss what happens with vs. without insurance.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Insurance Match Game
Materials Needed: Cards with types of insurance (health, car, home) and matching items/events
Steps to Follow: 1. Match event (e.g., car crash) to insurance type. 2. Review matches.
What Should Be Achieved: Link insurance types to coverage.
What is Gained: Better grasp of how insurance works.
steps: 1. Match event (e.g., car crash) to insurance type. 2. Review matches.
gained: Better grasp of how insurance works.

objective: To learn basic principles of supply and demand in markets.
explanation:
• · When many people want something, the price goes up.
• · When there is too much of something, the price may go down.
• · This helps set prices in the economy.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Lemonade Stand Role-Play
Materials Needed: Cups, paper signs with prices, pretend money
Steps to Follow: 1. Set up a pretend lemonade stand. 2. Adjust price based on number of customers.
What Should Be Achieved: See demand affect price.
What is Gained: Hands-on pricing experience.
steps: 1. Set up a pretend lemonade stand. 2. Adjust price based on number of customers.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Price Prediction Game
Materials Needed: Scenario cards (e.g., “popular toy” or “too many apples”)
Steps to Follow: 1. Read each scenario. 2. Predict whether price will rise or fall.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand supply and demand trends.
What is Gained: Market logic thinking.
steps: 1. Read each scenario. 2. Predict whether price will rise or fall.

objective: To understand how businesses are built and run.
explanation:
• · Businesses provide goods or services and earn money.
• · They need a plan, team, and good decisions.
• · Being creative and solving problems is key to business success.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Mini Start-Up Plan
Materials Needed: Planning sheet, crayons, pencils
Steps to Follow: 1. Child chooses a pretend business idea. 2. Draw/store what’s needed (location, tools, team).
What Should Be Achieved: Create basic business idea.
What is Gained: Entrepreneurial thinking.
steps: 1. Child chooses a pretend business idea. 2. Draw/store what’s needed (location, tools, team).

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Business Simulation
Materials Needed: Play money, signs, items to “sell”
Steps to Follow: 1. Assign roles (CEO, worker, customer). 2. Run shop: buy, sell, earn.
What Should Be Achieved: Simulate running a business.
What is Gained: Teamwork, profit/loss understanding.
steps: 1. Assign roles (CEO, worker, customer). 2. Run shop: buy, sell, earn.

objective: To explore what it costs to live in different places.
explanation:
• · Every place has different prices for food, housing, and clothes.
• · Cost of living affects how far our money goes.
• · Budgeting changes based on location.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
City Comparison Activity
Materials Needed: Item price lists from two cities
Steps to Follow: 1. Compare prices of food, rent, etc. in both cities. 2. Circle which is cheaper.
What Should Be Achieved: Spot location-based differences.
What is Gained: Budgeting awareness by region.
materials: Item price lists from two cities
steps: 1. Compare prices of food, rent, etc. in both cities. 2. Circle which is cheaper.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Lifestyle Budgeting Game
Materials Needed: Budget sheet, pretend salaries
Steps to Follow: 1. Choose a city to “live” in. 2. Create a budget that fits local cost of living.
What Should Be Achieved: Adapt spending to location.
What is Gained: Flexibility in personal finance planning.
steps: 1. Choose a city to “live” in. 2. Create a budget that fits local cost of living.

objective: To learn how to plan and predict outcomes in money decisions.
explanation:
• · A decision tree helps map out choices and consequences.
• · It shows what might happen if we choose one path over another.
• · This helps us make smarter money decisions.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Create a Money Tree
Materials Needed: Paper, pencils
Steps to Follow: 1. Choose a financial choice (save vs. spend). 2. Branch out different outcomes. 3. Add consequences.
What Should Be Achieved: Visualize results of choices.
What is Gained: Logical thinking and planning.
steps: 1. Choose a financial choice (save vs. spend). 2. Branch out different outcomes. 3. Add consequences.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
What If Scenario
Materials Needed: Scenario cards with money choices
Steps to Follow: 1. Read situation. 2. Predict outcomes for 2–3 different actions. 3. Discuss the best path.
What Should Be Achieved: Analyze options.
What is Gained: Critical thinking in finance.
steps: 1. Read situation. 2. Predict outcomes for 2–3 different actions. 3. Discuss the best path.

objective: To differentiate between earning money and building long-term wealth.
explanation:
• · Income is the money we earn regularly (like allowance or salary).
• · Wealth is what we save, invest, and own.
• · Wealth grows over time, not just through earning.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Income Sources Brainstorm
Materials Needed: Whiteboard or paper
Steps to Follow: 1. List all ways people earn money (jobs, rent, investments). 2. Classify as income or wealth-building.
What Should Be Achieved: Spot difference between income and assets.
What is Gained: Clear definitions of money terms.
steps: 1. List all ways people earn money (jobs, rent, investments). 2. Classify as income or wealth
building.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:

Materials Needed: Chart paper, markers
Steps to Follow: 1. Create a graph showing weekly savings or investing. 2. Track how money grows over time.
What Should Be Achieved: Visualize long-term gain.
What is Gained: Understanding of wealth accumulation.

objective: To explore different types of economic systems and how they function.
explanation:

• · Common systems include capitalism, socialism, and mixed economies.

Materials Needed: Chart paper, markers
Steps to Follow: 1. Draw columns for each economic system. 2. Add key features under each.
What Should Be Achieved: Visualize and compare economic models.
What is Gained: Understanding system differences.
steps: 1. Draw columns for each economic system. 2. Add key features under each.

activities.originalText:

Materials Needed: World map, country tags
Steps to Follow: 1. Assign countries to capitalism, socialism, or mixed. 2. Discuss why.
What Should Be Achieved: Connect systems to real-world nations.
What is Gained: Global awareness of economies.

What is Gained: Smarter borrowing decisions.

objective: To understand how inflation affects the value of money.
explanation:
• · Inflation means prices rise over time, reducing purchasing power.
• · Even if income stays the same, inflation makes money buy less.
• · Savings must grow faster than inflation to maintain value.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Price Comparison Over Time
Materials Needed: Old newspapers, internet access, paper, pen
Steps to Follow: 1. List common items (e.g., milk, shoes, movie ticket). 2. Research prices from the past and compare with current ones.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand how prices rise over time.
What is Gained: Grasp of inflation and its effect on spending.
steps: 1. List common items (e.g., milk, shoes, movie ticket). 2. Research prices from the past and compare with current ones.
activities.achieved: Understand how prices rise over time.
gained: Grasp of inflation and its effect on spending.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Inflation Tracker
Materials Needed: Graph paper, markers
Steps to Follow: 1. Plot prices of one item over different years. 2. Discuss the trend and impact on purchasing power.
What Should Be Achieved: Visual representation of inflation.
What is Gained: Clear understanding of how inflation erodes money value.
steps: 1. Plot prices of one item over different years. 2. Discuss the trend and impact on purchasing power.
gained: Clear understanding of how inflation erodes money value.

What is Gained: Decision-making around loans.

objective: To learn how wealth grows through planning and consistent action.
explanation:
• · Wealth comes from saving, investing, and managing money wisely.
• · Time, discipline, and smart decisions matter more than luck.
• · Avoiding debt and increasing assets is key.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Wealth Timeline
Materials Needed: Timeline chart, stickers or markers
Steps to Follow: 1. Plot key financial goals over a lifetime. 2. Add steps like saving and investing.
What Should Be Achieved: See long-term money growth.
What is Gained: Motivation and goal-setting skills.
steps: 1. Plot key financial goals over a lifetime. 2. Add steps like saving and investing.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Financial Life Map
Materials Needed: Drawing paper, pencils
Steps to Follow: 1. Create two maps: one with smart financial moves and one with poor choices. 2. Compare outcomes.
What Should Be Achieved: Visualize paths to and away from wealth.
What is Gained: Perspective on financial decision-making.

objective: Understand how countries interact financially through trade and currency.
explanation:
• · The global economy connects nations via imports, exports, and currency exchange.
• · Exchange rates affect how much things cost internationally.
• · Trade agreements influence jobs and prices.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Trade Simulation
Materials Needed: Play money, country cards, goods tokens
Steps to Follow: 1. Assign countries and goods to students. 2. Simulate trading goods and currency exchange. 3. Discuss advantages and challenges.
What Should Be Achieved: Experience of international trade and exchange rates.
What is Gained: Understanding of how economies depend on each other.
steps: 1. Assign countries and goods to students. 2. Simulate trading goods and currency exchange. 3. Discuss advantages and challenges.
activities.achieved: Experience of international trade and exchange rates.
gained: Understanding of how economies depend on each other.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Exchange Rate Tracker
Materials Needed: Internet access, calculator, worksheet
Steps to Follow: 1. Look up current exchange rates. 2. Convert prices of common items between currencies. 3. Reflect on cost differences.
What Should Be Achieved: Real-life context of currency values.
What is Gained: Awareness of global price variation and exchange rate influence.

objective: Learn how insurance helps manage financial risk.
explanation:
• · Insurance protects against loss (car, health, property).
• · Premiums are paid regularly, and claims provide compensation.
• · Understanding deductibles, coverage, and types is important.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Insurance Match Game
Materials Needed: Insurance type cards, scenario cards
Steps to Follow: 1. Match each insurance type to real-life scenarios. 2. Discuss what the insurance covers.
What Should Be Achieved: Clear grasp of when and why insurance is used.
What is Gained: Insight into financial protection strategies.

objective: Explore how income tax works and how it's filed.
explanation:
• · People pay income tax based on earnings.
• · Tax returns report income, deductions, and refunds.
• · Filing taxes is a yearly responsibility.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Tax Form Activity
Materials Needed: Simplified tax form templates, calculators
Steps to Follow: 1. Fill out a mock return with provided income and deductions. 2. Calculate tax due or refund.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand the process of tax filing.
What is Gained: Confidence in handling future tax responsibilities.
steps: 1. Fill out a mock return with provided income and deductions. 2. Calculate tax due or refund.
activities.achieved: Understand the process of tax filing.
gained: Confidence in handling future tax responsibilities.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Income Breakdown
Materials Needed: Sample pay stub, worksheet
Steps to Follow: 1. Identify gross vs. net income. 2. Note tax deductions and their purposes.
What Should Be Achieved: Realize how taxes affect take-home pay.
What is Gained: Practical awareness of earning and deductions.

objective: Learn how buying, renting, and investing in property works.
explanation:
• · Real estate involves buying, selling, or renting property.
• · Property can increase in value (appreciation).
• · Ownership has responsibilities like taxes and maintenance.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Rent vs. Buy Debate
Materials Needed: Debate prompt cards, comparison chart
Steps to Follow: 1. Divide into teams. 2. Debate pros and cons of renting vs. owning a home.
What Should Be Achieved: Weigh both sides of a major life decision.
What is Gained: Critical thinking on long-term financial choices.
steps: 1. Divide into teams. 2. Debate pros and cons of renting vs. owning a home.

activities.name: Activity 2

Materials Needed: Sample listings, budget sheets
Steps to Follow: 1. Compare properties based on price, location, and features. 2. Choose best investment.
What Should Be Achieved: Make informed property choices.
What is Gained: Strategic decision-making in real estate.

objective: Understand the financial implications of college and alternatives.
explanation:
• · College has costs: tuition, housing, books, etc.
• · Scholarships, loans, and savings (e.g., 529 plans) help pay.
• · Trade schools and apprenticeships are other options.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
College Budget
Materials Needed: Expense worksheet, college cost info
Steps to Follow: 1. Create a budget for one year of college. 2. Include scholarships, loans, and jobs.
What Should Be Achieved: Know real costs of higher education.
What is Gained: Budgeting and financial planning skills.

Steps to Follow: 1. Compare cost and return of college, trade school, and working early. 2. Reflect on choices.
What Should Be Achieved: Evaluate education value vs. cost.
What is Gained: Career and financial planning perspective.

objective: Explore paycheck components and employee benefits.
explanation:

• · Benefits may include health insurance, retirement plans, and bonuses.

activities.originalText:

Materials Needed: Sample pay stubs
Steps to Follow: 1. Identify gross pay, taxes, benefits, and net pay. 2. Understand where deductions go.
What Should Be Achieved: Learn how to read a paycheck.
What is Gained: Job evaluation and budgeting skills.

objective: Learn how financial decisions can align with values.
explanation:
• · Ethical finance includes choosing eco-friendly, fair-trade, or socially responsible investments.
• · Money choices can support causes or avoid harm.
• · Sustainability matters in business and personal finance.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Ethics Sort
Materials Needed: Scenario cards with ethical and unethical choices
Steps to Follow: 1. Sort financial behaviors into “Responsible” or “Harmful.” 2. Discuss outcomes.
What Should Be Achieved: Learn to evaluate money choices ethically.
What is Gained: Moral reasoning and ethical finance skills.

objective: Understand the evolution of banking with technology.
explanation:
• · Fintech includes digital wallets, online banks, and investment apps.
• · Convenience is high, but cybersecurity is crucial.
• · Staying informed about digital tools is key.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
App Comparison
Materials Needed: Research sheets, comparison chart
Steps to Follow: 1. Explore 2–3 banking or payment apps. 2. Compare features, pros, and cons.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand different financial tools.
What is Gained: Tech literacy in modern banking.

objective: Plan strategies for growing wealth over decades.
explanation:
• · Wealth building involves saving, investing, and avoiding bad debt.
• · Compound interest and smart investing are crucial.
• · Consistency over time makes a big difference.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Retirement Challenge
Materials Needed: Calculator, worksheet
Steps to Follow: 1. Calculate how much saving $5/week can grow in 40 years. 2. Discuss results with compound interest.
What Should Be Achieved: Realize power of consistent saving.
What is Gained: Motivation to start early and build wealth.

What is Gained: Long-term vision and financial planning skills.
